author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body: This package is used in several science projects and referenced in the respective Project.toml. In order to support Open Science, the package needs to be accessible by the broad community and therefore to be registered at General.

Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Hi @bgctw, and thank you for contributing to the ecosystem!
I am not sure this package really needs to be registered. Based on the docs, it mostly contains three small and very different utilities, which suggests that it is a collection of utilities for your projects, not necessarily for the community at large.
If you want to use it in your open science endeavors (which I support!), maybe a [local registry](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl) would be an option? Alternately, you can try to contribute these utilities to the relevant packages and see what they think?

PS: This comment will pause the registration for now. Anyone can do that, I don't have any registry maintainer privileges.

Thanks @gdalle for looking into it.

Yes, as the package description says, it is a collection of functionality that has not found its proper place/project yet. As I understood the suggested local registry, its intended for "local" work. However, for reproducible science, I would need a publicly accessible Registry. Do you know of such a registry hosted by an institution that can provide such packages that are not suitable for General?

I have never used LocalRegistry myself but I think you can host said registry on a public GitHub repository. Although it's probably more useful if you have several such packages to maintain together. For a single one, you can just keep it in a plain GitHub repo and add it with its URL to downstream projects. You will also need to check the Manifest.toml of these downstream projects into GitHub

Thanks again.
The suggestion of [adding it as unregistered public github package](https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/managing-packages/#Adding-unregistered-packages) seems to fit my use case.  Hence, this package does not need to be registered with General.
Perfect! This PR will expire automatically without further action needed

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
